instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Clean 00239, no liquid, with no power. Board has ppbus (13.2v) and 20v on USB-C power input (0W/0A draw), but not much else. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is missing completely. Thought it might be the SMC since signal was missing completely, but replaced SMC and symptoms persist. Also replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> to be safe. SMC power (<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_SMC_VDD</SIGNAL>) is present. I have .4v at L7960, and no damage or anything around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. All related pull-up resistors for <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5192</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R8110</RESISTOR>) measuring fine. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> signals all high.

Is this possibly a <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> power issue? Nothing gets warm, no shorts on <SIGNAL>S5_HS</SIGNAL>, etc. Everything stops at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. All help appreciated!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Do you have 87W charger for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Yes, definitely using a proper 87W charger for all testing. Any other ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> requires <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> to work.
Battery is charging?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
I can't tell if battery is charging; how would I determine that with no board life? I have 0W/0A draw on all USB-C ports.

If the SMC isn't at fault for the missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, what else should I be looking at? Could <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> be pulling <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> down, which is why it's missing? Would love to not screw around with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> if I don't need to. ;)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Check if possible to cut off the trace, before <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
If not, should remove it and see if signal comes high.

If no current drawn from charger, battery is not charging; secondary effect of missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> I suppose.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Sounds good, I'll do that. But quick question: Obviously I don't want to apply power with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> removed; how should I check if signal comes high with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Puah, good question...
You MUST remove several MOSFETs from the secondary power supplies controlled by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>; <CHIP>U7900</CHIP>/60, <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>/50.
Be sure I didn't forget any to mention...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Sure thing, thank you; I'll try that. I may even just replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> since I'm having to pull it, and I have spares. Will try that and let you know--thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Bit of a newb question here, but what all is required by the SMC on this model to actually produce <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>? I replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and no dice, exact same behavior. Curious if I'm missing an input for SMC that should be present. These touchbar boards really throw me for a loop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Very strange, as getting 20V from charger means SMC talks with it.
So SMC is in working condition.
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> must be high on S5 state if charger is connected.
If SMC already talked with tthe charger I don't know if needs other signal about charger presence; which looks like redundant in such case.
However check <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL>; corresponds to ACOK.
